title: 114_s211
content: The "Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area Act" establishes the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area, with definitions for terms like Heritage Area, local coordinating entity, management plan, Secretary, and State. The Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area is established in Pennsylvania, including Lancaster and York Counties. A local coordinating entity is designated for the area. The Susquehanna Heritage Corporation, a nonprofit organization, is designated as the local coordinating entity for the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area in Pennsylvania. The entity has the authority to use Federal funds for various purposes such as preparing reports, making grants, entering into agreements, and hiring staff. The local coordinating entity for the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area in Pennsylvania has the authority to use Federal funds for various purposes, including preparing a management plan, implementing actions, goals, and strategies, and assisting in programs that recognize and protect important resource values in the Heritage Area. The local coordinating entity for the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area in Pennsylvania can use Federal funds for purposes such as encouraging economic viability, establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational and educational opportunities, increasing public awareness, restoring historic buildings, and installing clear signage throughout the Heritage Area. The local coordinating entity in the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area can use Federal funds for various purposes, including installing clear signage, considering diverse interests in the management plan, conducting public meetings regularly, and submitting annual reports on accomplishments and finances. The local coordinating entity in the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area must disclose expenses, income, and grant recipients, provide audit records for Federal funds, and prohibit using funds for real property acquisition. The local coordinating entity in the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area can use Federal funds from other sources for authorized purposes, including acquiring real property or any interest in real property. The management plan for the Susquehanna Gateway National Heritage Area allows the local coordinating entity to use Federal funds for acquiring real property or interests in real property. The local coordinating entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of receiving funds for the Heritage Area. The plan should include policies, strategies, funding sources, and an inventory of resources to be preserved, managed, and developed. The management plan for the Heritage Area must be submitted to the Secretary within 3 years of receiving funds. It should include policies, strategies, funding sources, and an inventory of resources to be preserved, managed, and developed. Recommendations for coordinating Federal, State, and local programs are also required. If the plan is not submitted within the specified timeframe, additional funding may be withheld until it is received. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan within 180 days of submission by the local coordinating entity. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan submitted by the local coordinating entity within 180 days. Factors considered include the entity's representation of diverse interests, public and governmental involvement, and resource protection and interpretation. The management plan must be approved or disapproved by the Secretary within 180 days. Factors considered include diverse interests representation, public and governmental involvement, resource protection, and interpretation strategies. If disapproved, the Secretary must provide written reasons to the local coordinating entity. The Secretary must approve or disapprove a revised management plan within 180 days. Substantial amendments to the plan must also be approved before any changes can be implemented using funds appropriated under the Act. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. In general, this Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and local coordinating entity. The Act does not change laws or regulations regarding Federal land management or limit the discretion of Federal land managers within the Heritage Area. SEC. 7. PRIVATE PROPERTY AND REGULATORY PROTECTIONS. The Act does not limit property owners' rights, including the right to opt out of Heritage Area activities, restrict public access to private property, change existing land use regulations, or claim water rights. The Heritage Area Act does not limit property owners' rights, including the right to opt out of activities, restrict public access, change land use regulations, or claim water rights. It also prohibits any actions that diminish the State's authority to manage fish and wildlife or create liability for private property owners regarding injuries on their property. SEC. 8. EVALUATION; REPORT. The Secretary must conduct an evaluation of the Heritage Area's accomplishments and prepare a report before Federal funding ends. The evaluation will assess the local entity's progress in meeting the Act's purposes and management plan goals, analyze investments, and review the management structure and partnerships. The Secretary will review the management structure, partnership relationships, and funding of the Heritage Area to identify critical components for sustainability. A report will be prepared with recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service, including an analysis of ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding if reauthorization is recommended. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress, including recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service and ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 is authorized to carry out the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Federal share of costs for activities funded should not exceed 50%. Termination of Authority: The Secretary's ability to provide financial assistance under the Act ends 15 years after enactment.
